label: 行勇
本: Jewel in the Ashes: Buddha Relics and Power in Early Medieval Japan . Harvard University Asia Center . 2000
説明文: Gyōyū (J.) 行勇, also called 荘厳房, 退耕和尚 Shōgonbō, Taikō wajō. A monk who took residence early on in Tsurugaoka Hachimangū shrine in Kamakura and conferred the precepts on Hōjō Masako, Gyōy・studied under the Zen monk Eisai and received the seal transmission from the master. However, when Masako established Kongōzanmai'in at Mount Kōya in 1223, she sent Gyōyūthere; proceeding to study under the Ono branch monk 道範 Dōhan (1178-1252) there, Gyōyū established a place of practice for the pursuit of esoteric teachings, the precepts, and Zen. Invited by Hōjō Yasutoki, Gyōyū returned to Kamakura and took residence in Jufukuji in 1239, and later opened the temples Jōmyōji and Tōshōji at the request of Yasutoki.
